unnormalised: The Bombay High Court has issued a notice to the Maharashtra state government regarding the alleged violation of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948, by several private companies. Adv. Rohan Sharma filed a PIL on 10/10/2024, citing instances where employees were reportedly paid below the stipulated minimum wage of Rs. 18,000 per month. The court has sought a response from the government within 4 weeks.
normalised: The Bombay High Court has issued a notice to the Maharashtra state government regarding the alleged violation of the Minimum Wages Act, one thousand nine hundred and forty eight, by several private companies. Advocate Rohan Sharma filed a P-I-L on tenth October two thousand and twenty four, citing instances where employees were reportedly paid below the stipulated minimum wage of rupee eighteen thousand per month. The court has sought a response from the government within four weeks.

unnormalised: The petition highlights several cases from the Mumbai Metropolitan Region (MMR), including instances where daily wage laborers were paid as little as Rs. 400 per day, far below the legal requirement. The PIL also references the Contract Labour (Regulation and Abolition) Act, 1970, alleging that several companies have failed to provide adequate benefits and working conditions for contractual employees. A hearing is scheduled for 15/11/2024.
normalised: The petition highlights several cases from the Mumbai Metropolitan Region (M-M-R), including instances where daily wage laborers were paid as little as rupee four hundred per day, far below the legal requirement. The P-I-L also references the Contract Labour (Regulation and Abolition) Act, one thousand nine hundred and seventy, alleging that several companies have failed to provide adequate benefits and working conditions for contractual employees. A hearing is scheduled for fifteenth November two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: The case is expected to shed light on the implementation and enforcement of labor laws in the state. Unions are closely watching the developments, hoping it will lead to stricter regulations and increased protection for workers. The case ID is PIL/2024/123.
